author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
name: CameraShake
description: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
- Short shaking can be used to give impact (explosion, hit)
- Shaking can go indefinitely to set an ambiance (engine vibration, earthquake, pulsing)
- Low frequency shaking allows to simulate slow moving objects (ship rocking back and forth)
- No adaptation of the game events is needed.
- It fixes an issue when used with scrolling, the amplitude will feel bigger in this case.
- The shaking relies on noise which could feel a bit different.
- This extension can no longer do impulses. For this, another extension "Camera impulse" can be used.

events.comment: Use user defined default values when there is no layer specific value set.

Shake the layer camera.
Save the camera displacement to revert it in onScenePostEvents.

eventsFunctions.description: Shake the camera on layers chosen with configuration actions.
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeCamera
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera for _PARAM1_ seconds with _PARAM2_ seconds of easing to start and _PARAM3_ seconds to stop

eventsFunctions.description: Shake the camera on the specified layer, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, zoom). This action is deprecated. Please use the other one with the same name.
eventsFunctions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

events.comment: Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeY

eventsFunctions.description: Start shaking the camera indefinitely.
eventsFunctions.name: StartShaking
eventsFunctions.sentence: Start shaking the camera with _PARAM1_ seconds of easing

eventsFunctions.description: Stop shaking the camera.
eventsFunctions.name: StopShaking
eventsFunctions.sentence: Stop shaking the camera with _PARAM1_ seconds of easing

eventsFunctions.description: Mark a layer as shakable.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLayerShakable
eventsFunctions.sentence: Mark the layer: _PARAM2_ as shakable: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the camera is shaking.
eventsFunctions.name: IsShaking
eventsFunctions.sentence: Camera is shaking

eventsFunctions.description: Change the translation amplitude of the shaking (in pixels).

parameters.name: AmplitudeX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (in pixels)

eventsFunctions.description: Change the rotation amplitude of the shaking (in degrees).
eventsFunctions.name: SetLayerRotationAmplitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the rotation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ degrees (layer: _PARAM2_)

eventsFunctions.description: Change the zoom factor amplitude of the shaking. The shaking will zoom and unzoom by this factor (for instance 1.0625 is a valid value).
eventsFunctions.name: SetLayerZoomAmplitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the zoom factor amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ (layer: _PARAM2_)

eventsFunctions.description: Change the number of back and forth per seconds.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLayerShakingFrequency
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the shaking frequency to _PARAM1_ (layer: _PARAM2_)

eventsFunctions.description: Change the default translation amplitude of the shaking (in pixels).
eventsFunctions.name: SetDefaultTranslationAmplitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the default translation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_; _PARAM2_

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (in pixels)

parameters.name: AmplitudeY

eventsFunctions.description: Change the default rotation amplitude of the shaking (in degrees).
eventsFunctions.name: SetDefaultRotationAmplitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the default rotation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ degrees

eventsFunctions.description: Change the default zoom factor amplitude of the shaking. The shaking will zoom and unzoom by this factor (for instance 1.0625 is a valid value).
eventsFunctions.name: SetDefaultZoomAmplitude
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the default zoom factor amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the default number of back and forth per seconds.
eventsFunctions.name: SetDefaultShakingFrequency
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the default shaking frequency to _PARAM1_

inlineCode: * Create the manager of noise generators.
* Create a noise generator with a seed.
// Make the circle perimeter equals to the looping period
// to keep the same perceived frequency with or without looping.
noiseSum += noiseFunction(x * frequency, y * frequency, z * frequency, w * frequency) * amplitude;
A fast javascript implementation of simplex noise by Jonas Wagner
Based on a speed-improved simplex noise algorithm for 2D, 3D and 4D in Java.
Which is based on example code by Stefan Gustavson (stegu@itn.liu.se).
Better rank ordering method by Stefan Gustavson in 2012.

/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]
* This is exported only for (internal) testing purposes.
* Do not rely on this export.
The ALEA PRNG and masher code used by simplex-noise.js
is based on code by Johannes Baagøe, modified by Jonas Wagner.
See alea.md for the full license.

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 2 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise2d

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 3 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise3d

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 4 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise4d

eventsFunctions.description: Create a noise generator with default settings (frequency = 1,  octaves = 1, persistence = 0.5, lacunarity = 2).
eventsFunctions.name: Create
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create a noise generator named _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Delete a noise generator and loose its settings.
eventsFunctions.name: Delete
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delete _PARAM1_ noise generator

eventsFunctions.description: Delete all noise generators and loose their settings.
eventsFunctions.name: DeleteAll
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delete all noise generators

eventsFunctions.description: The seed is a number used to generate the random noise. Setting the same seed will result in the same random noise generation. It's for example useful to generate the same world, by saving this seed value and reusing it later to generate again a world.
eventsFunctions.name: SetSeed
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise seed to _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on X used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on X.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodX
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on X of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on Y used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on Y.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodY
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on Y of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the base frequency used for noise generation. A lower frequency will zoom in the noise.
eventsFunctions.name: SetFrequency
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise frequency of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the number of octaves used for noise generation. It can be seen as layers of noise with different zoom.
eventsFunctions.name: SetOctaves
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the number of noise octaves of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the persistence used for noise generation. At its default value "0.5", it halves the noise amplitude at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetPersistence
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise persistence of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the lacunarity used for noise generation. At its default value "2", it doubles the frequency at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLacunarity
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise lacunarity of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: The seed used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Seed

eventsFunctions.description: The base frequency used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Frequency

eventsFunctions.description: The number of octaves used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Octaves

eventsFunctions.description: The persistence used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Persistence

eventsFunctions.description: The lacunarity used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Lacunarity
